titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Causeries du Lundi Records
1880-1996 (bulk 1880-1974)
MS 104
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Processed by Anna Helgeson, 2007 with additions by Catherine Newton, 2012

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from causeries.xml

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-11-12T11:36-0500

did.abstract: This collection includes member and meeting information of the women's writing group, Causeries du Lundi, founded in 1880 and still active today. Members of this group write and present their essays at meetings, gathering the first Monday of every month in the winter.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. (Researchers may not accrue unused copy amounts from previous days.)

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
The Causeries du Lundi owns the copyright and other intellectual property rights to their materials. Permission to quote from this collection in a publication must be requested and granted in writing from the Causeries du Lundi as well as the New-York Historical Society. Send permission requests to
Library Director
The New-York Historical Society
Two West 77th Street
New York, NY 10024

The copyright law of the United States governs the making of photocopies and protects unpublished materials as well as published materials. Unpublished materials created before January 1, 1978 cannot be quoted in publication without permission of the copyright holder.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as the Causeries du Lundi Records, The New-York Historical Society.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Causeries du Lundi is one the oldest women's literary societies in the U.S. still active today. Elizabeth Hamilton Collum, the granddaughter of Alexander Hamilton, founded the group in 1880 (Anniversary Book, 1930). Collum believed in a "better future for American women than a life of frivolity" and encouraged members to own and express opinions outside of home and social duties and document their interests in art, literature and scholarly culture.

Today, the group meets at a member's home on the first Monday of every winter month. Generally, only one paper per meeting is read, either by the author or another member. As many members come from prominent New York families, the papers provide insight into their family histories as well as old New York, while topics most often include ancestry, art, travel or historical subjects. Causeries du Lundi incorporated in 2008 and is now known as Causeries du Lundi 1880, Inc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Causeries du Lundi records are arranged in seven series: President's books, Anniversary books, Annual Reports, Minutes, Member's Essays and Invitations. The bulk of the records are from 1880 to 1974. The majority of the collection consists of the essays written by Causerie members.

The collection documents the founding and administration of the group, its membership, and papers presented by the Causeries du Lundi. The Rules of Government state protocol and procedures of joining and maintaining membership in the Causeries du Lundi.The President's Books detail membership listings, addresses, schedules, and paper topics. Anniversary books were published in celebration of the passing of the years and provide history of the organization and its members. Annual reports and Minutes detail meeting and hostess information, with synopses of presented papers and ensuing discussion, as well as treasury reports. Member files are arranged alphabetically and contain the essays of the members. Some files may also contain clippings, comments and correspondence relating to the essays.

The Causeries du Lundi records contain many essays by women of prominent New York backgrounds with last names such as Lefferts, Peabody, Roosevelt, Delano, Erving, Pierrepont and Parsons, to name a few. One paper of historical interest was submitted by Mrs. Edward Curtis, whose husband performed Abraham Lincoln's autopsy. She included an article written by her husband in 1926 about the event.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged within the following seven series:

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at The New-York Historical Society
relatedmaterial.p:
Further material about the Causeries du Lundi is located at the New-York Historical Society within the
Erving-King Papers.

Societies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes printed material detailing the protocol of membership and governing committees in the Causeries du Lundi.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: President's books contain membership information as well as meeting schedules, including the hostess and paper topic lists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains printed books celebrating the anniversaries of and detailing the history of the organization and its members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Annual reports contain meeting and budget information. After 1901, annual reports are kept with the meeting minutes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Minutes detail meeting and hostess information, with synopses of presented papers and ensuing discussion, as well as the group's treasury reports. Book numbers are taken from the cover of notebook or binder of the minutes. Many have been removed from their binder for preservation purposes, but a representative sample of the binders is available at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains members' essay files with corresponding dates. There is a chronological list of all papers at the beginning of the series. Most papers are 10-30 pages in length, most having been transcribed and typewritten and usually pertain to art, ancestral or historical topics. Some files contain clippings and other miscellaneous notes. If there are more than four papers in a file, the range of dates is given. Member's files are arranged alphabetically and are arranged as their names appear in their papers.

did.unittitle: Mrs. T. Guthrie Spears, Jr. (Susan Savage)
Mrs. Henry A. Stickney (Helen Morgan Frick)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of ten printed invitations to Causeries du Lundi meetings.
